III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
Section (2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a youth is
Description placed in independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements for the
specific program the youth is being placed into.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not adequately document how youth met eligibility
requirements for independent living prior to Independent Living
(IL) placement.
Investigation Complainant was DCWL as different complaint was received
if IL placement was appropriate for youth.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on August 24, 2023. She stated she was assigned to
Youth A’s case just prior to him entering into the ILP program. She
stated Youth A had been in a fictive kin placement since February
2023 prior to ILP placement. The agency participated in a concern
meeting with other providers who had been working with Youth A.
There were some concerns regarding his school attendance but
there were a lot of strengths discussed as well. Youth A can be
very efficient and self-sufficient, but he could also make selfish
choices. A new placement needed to be found due to the fictive
kin placement allowing Youth A to have contact with his biological
mother who had her parental rights terminated. FC supervisor
stated the agency made several attempts to locate a new
placement for Youth A. They were evaluating family members and
made an RPU referral but was unable to find an appropriate
placement. Youth A went AWOL and notified the agency several
times that he did not want to go to residential and if he is sent to
residential, he will leave and not be found.
FC supervisor reported approximately May 18, 2023, during a
concern meeting the idea of independent living was brought up.
The discussion centered around finding an IL program that had
supportive components so Youth A could learn the skills needed
to live independently. Three more concern meetings were held to
discuss placement options. All placement options were explored
and evaluated.
FC supervisor was asked about the most recent Parent Agency
Treatment Plan (PATP) prior to Youth A being referred to ILP. The
PATP stated Youth A was not ready to live independently. She
stated the discussion during meetings involving Youth A was that
he had the core abilities and capabilities to take care of himself.
He did well during his placement with fictive kin and initially at the
ILP placement. Some of the criteria mentioned in the PATP
involve parenting and housing which are things Youth A had never
experienced so in regard to those aspects Youth A was not
prepared for IL. The agency had referred other youth to this
2

specific ILP program and were aware of the programming they
had to offer and outcomes with other youth.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
August 29, 2023. FCW stated she has been asking to Youth A’s
case since March 2023. Upon being assigned the case FCW
stated there had already been ongoing discussion regarding
referring Youth A to an IL program. She stated she was under the
impression he was going to be or already accepted into an IL
program through another agency. The initial referral to an IL
program was denied due to his behaviors while in residential.
While he was in fictive kin placement Youth A was doing well. He
was attending school, making good decisions and assisting with
household chores.
FCW stated he was referred to an ILP because of the supports the
program offered for youth. The understanding of the agency was
the program was meant for teaching youth independent living
skills that were not already there. She stated he had some
independent living skills but did not have all of them and wouldn’t
have been appropriate to live on his own. The program he was
referred to was a group home setting with someone checking in 5
days per week that would assist him with IL skills.
Foster Care supervisor 2 (FC supervisor 2) was interviewed
on August 30, 2023. FC supervisor 2 stated she was not
assigned to Youth A’s case at the time he entered ILP but had
been assigned just prior to that. Youth A had been in a residential
program and then moved to a fictive kin placement. While in the
fictive kin placement Youth A did well and was able to
demonstrate some independent living skills. Due to concerns with
fictive kin allowing Youth A to have contact with his biological
mother who had her parental rights terminated the agency was
looking into other placement options. Due to his age, length of
time in the system and level of functioning while in fictive kin
placement the agency started looking into ILP programs. The
agency had also considered options of treatment foster care and
Wraparound. FC supervisor 2 was asked if, based on Youth A’s
past behavioral concerns, if there were any concerns about him
not being ready for IL or ILP. She stated there is always some
concerns regarding readiness for IL when you’re referring 16- and
17-year-olds. Youth with trauma usually have some behaviors.
The ILP programs are helpful due to the staffing and support that
is available. The agency was looking into all of the least restrictive
placement options.
3

Documents reviewed:
• April 20, 2023, PATP for Youth A authored by referring
Child Placing Agency staff states under independent
living section: “As of 4/20/23, Youth A is unable to live
independently. Youth A scores as adequate in education,
daily living skills, and preventive health skills. Youth A lacks
adequate parenting skills however is not an expectant
parent. His lack of appropriate behavior would impede his
ability to adequately and safely provide for a young child.
Youth A lacks money management and budgeting skills
due to his lack of experience in money management. Once
behaviors are appropriate, he will also be referred to MYOI.
Housing and community resources also remains
inadequate for Youth A as he has no experience for being
solely responsible for managing a household and is unable
to obtain independent housing at this time. He also lacks
the supportive adults with which to be able to rent a room
from for Independent Living. These needs will be
addressed by ISK wrap around, ETFC and Kalamazoo
Central High School. Youth A has not utilized any YIT funds
this quarter. He participated in a semi-annual transition plan
meeting on 3/28/23. On 12/27/22 an updated credit report
was run, and no credit history was found”.
• Referral email sent from referring Child Placing
Agency: includes referral form, immunization record for
Youth A, Youth A’s medical passport (unclear what date of
completion is), June 2023 AWOL petition, SSN verification,
March 2023 dental report, June 2022 psychological
evaluation, Jan 2023 emergency room visit, medication
refusal form, January 2023 medication review, school
grades, January 2015 Initial Service Plan, December 2019
termination of parental rights, June 2023 medical passport,
April 2023 FTM DHS 1105, Youth A’s birth certificate,
March 2023 Semi-annual transition plan DHS 901, and
April 2023 Permanent Ward Service Plan.
• April 20, 2023, Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP)
authored by referring Child Placing Agency staff: report
states Youth A is getting set up with services from ETFC
and ISK to build skills needed to be accepted into and
achieve in an ILP placement. PWSP documents past
suicidal ideation and attempt as well as concern Youth A
does not take his prescribed medication. Youth A would like
to be placed in an IL program.
• Review of SWC in MISACWIS case file: January 24,
2023, SWC states residential placement submitted a 30-
day notice for Youth A on January 18, 2023. January 26,
4

2023, TDM discusses Youth A broke into an apartment and
stole a bike which resulted in being charged with home
invasion and destruction of property. Multiple incidents of
AWOL, almost daily or every other day incidents while in
the placement. During an AWOL incident, Youth A stole
and consumed alcohol which resulted in him being treated
for alcohol poisoning. TDM contact notes Youth A has a
difficult time following rules and expectations. February 11,
2023, SWC: Youth A is lodged in the Saginaw County
Juvenile Detention Center. Law enforcement responded to
the residential placement due to Youth A using scissors as
a weapon toward staff. February 14, 2023, SWC: Youth A
has pending charges for larceny and felonious assault. ILP
referrals need to be made. February social work contacts
document discussion regarding IL with Youth A. FCW
informs Youth A that his behaviors at residential made it
difficult and felt his current relative placement is best.
March 8, 2023, SWC: Youth A participated in an ILP
interview. March 15, 2023, SWC: Youth A was accepted
into an ILP program in Detroit, but Youth A was hesitant
due to the location. April 6, 2023, SWC: Youth A reports he
has a scheduled interview on April 10, 2023, with an ILP in
Bloomfield. SWC on April 12, 2023, states Youth A’s
application for IL placement was denied due to his
behaviors. DHS plans to reapply in 6 months.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. The agency’s decision to refer
Youth A into the ILP program was appropriate based on interviews
conducted and review of referral documentation as Youth A was
being referred in order to receive supports the ILP program offers
while residing on his own.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Moving forward it is recommended the agency be more thorough
in documenting rationale in service plans and treatment plans for
referring youth to IL or ILP.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
